key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning method learns compact, biologically meaningful representations of neuronal activity dynamics, enabling high-content, label-free screening that identifies genetic modifiers across diverse neural interventions.
problem_solved: Scales phenotypic screening of complex, time-varying neuronal activity without large labeled datasets or handcrafted features, overcoming heterogeneity and sensitivity issues in detecting subtle genetic effects on network dynamics.
method: Incorporate network/connectivity priors into self-supervised representation learning to respect cell–cell relationships while modeling temporal activity.
Design temporal and graph-based pretext tasks that force embeddings to capture dynamic phenotypes across interventions.
Deploy a scalable pipeline that maps perturbations to embedding space, clusters phenotypes, and ranks candidate genetic modifiers for follow-up.
impact: Provides ML practitioners with a label-efficient approach to discover functional phenotypes and perturbation effects from time-series networked data, improving transferability and interpretability for high-throughput biological screens.
visual_elements: Model schematic: nodes = neurons, edges = network priors, showing temporal SSL objectives feeding into an embedding space.
Embedding plot (UMAP/t-SNE) colored by perturbation/phenotype to show cluster separation and hit detection.
Time-series/heatmap panels comparing neuronal activity traces before and after key genetic perturbations.
End-to-end pipeline flowchart: data acquisition → network-aware SSL → phenotypic embedding → hit ranking/validation.
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
